item.title: Category theory for programmers â€“ Challenges 19.2 answers
item.dc:creator: ingun37
item.description: 1. Consider a free monoid built from a singleton set as its generator. Show that there is a one-to-one correspondence between morphisms from this free monoid to any monoid m, and functions from the singleton set to the underlying set of m. Think of the function that goes from singleton set to the Um as selecting which... Continue Reading →
item.content:encoded:
1. Consider a free monoid built from a singleton set as its generator. Show that there is a one-to-one correspondence between morphisms from this free monoid to any monoid m, and functions from the singleton set to the underlying set of m.

Think of the function that goes from singleton set to the Um as selecting which element in Um to be the unit. m would be a monoid that simply repeats the unit.

item.title: Category theory for programmers â€“ Challenges 18.5 answers
item.dc:creator: ingun37
item.description: Derive the naturality square for the transformation between the two (contravariant) functors: 2. Derive the counit starting from the hom-sets isomorphism in the second definition of the adjunction. It can be shown by replacing with 3. Complete the proof of equivalence of the two definitions of the adjunction. This is asking for the derivation from to since the... Continue Reading →
item.content:encoded:
1. Derive the naturality square for the transformation between the two (contravariant) functors:

2. Derive the counit starting from the hom-sets isomorphism in the second definition of the adjunction.

It can be shown by replacing with

3. Complete the proof of equivalence of the two definitions of the adjunction.

This is asking for the derivation from to since the other way is already described in the chapter.

Left one is when the is “below” the , and the right one is when the is “below” the . They are basically the same thing.

4. Show that the coproduct can be defined by an adjunction. Start with the definition of the factorizer for a coproduct.

5. Show that the coproduct is the left adjoint of the diagonal functor.

These two can be answered at once.

6. Define the adjunction between a product and a function object in Haskell.

This one I can’t figure out… maybe it’s asking to build something like this?

item.title: Easy Adjunctions with pictures
item.dc:creator: ingun37
item.description: I tried to represent the Adjunction as easy as possible using colors. Coloring related objects really helped me understanding Adjunctions better than any other explanations from posts/books. This is definition via hom-sets
item.content:encoded:
I tried to represent the Adjunction as easy as possible using colors.

Coloring related objects really helped me understanding Adjunctions better than any other explanations from posts/books.
